SafetyInspectionBy: API 510 In Service inspection of the ammonia tank

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Ammonia tank inspection, test emergency valve operation, test check valves, test unloading hoses
Ammonia tank inspection, test emergency valve operation, test check valves, test unloading hoses

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ANDERSONS MARATHON HOLDINGS LLC

Executive Summary

Site and Process Description



THE ANDERSONS MARATHON HOLDINGS LLC is located at 3389 West County Road 300 South.  The facility is located in Cass County, Clinton Township. The site is north of State road 25 and west of County Road 325 west. 



The Clymers facility operates 24 hours a day, 7 days a week with a staff of approximately 60 people.  The following operations are performed at this facility:  grain receiving and storage; hammer milling; fermentation; distillation, dehydration and evaporation (DDE); Corn oil extraction. Stillage and syrup is dried to produce DDGs (Dried Distillers Grain with soluble). The finished products are wet and dry distillers grain (WDGS / DDGS), corn oil, denatured ethanol, and E85 ethanol.  These products are shipped out via trucks and rail.



The plant receives corn by way of the pre-existing grain elevator or the new secondary truck dump at the ethanol plant.  Grain is stored temporarily in the concrete silos or steel grain bins, prior to being fed to four hammer mills where the corn is dry-milled into a powder and then conveyed to the production area.



The corn flour is mixed with water, enzymes, anhydrous ammonia and yeast; then is fermented to produce 13% ethanol beer.  The gases produced in fermentation are scrubbed with water to remove VOCs and then discharged to atmosphere. The beer is distilled to produce 190 proof ethanol and whole stillage. The 190 proof ethanol is dried to 200 proof and is denatured with gasoline to produce denatured ethanol and E85 ethanol finished products.  These products are shipped via rail or trucks.



The whole stillage is dried using evaporators and dryers to produce DDGs at 12% moisture or WDGS at 50% moisture.  DDGs is shipped via truck and rail.  The WDGS is shipped truck only.



Corn oil is extracted from the whole stillage. It is shipped by truck and rail.



Recuperative thermal oxidizers serve as the primary emission control devi

ces for the two dryers as well as various process vents.  The thermal oxidizers are very efficient at controlling particulates, carbon monoxide, VOC's, HAP's and nuisance odors.



The facility also has a water cooling tower for non-contact cooling water. Cooling is needed in distillation and fermentation. 



The facility is protected from fire with a high pressure fire water loop and sprinklers in high risk areas.   Also there is a central fire detection and alarm system. In the process area there are detection and alarm systems for CO2, VOC, and anhydrous.





RMP Applicability & Chemical Description



The two chemicals that require participation in the Risk Management Plan are anhydrous ammonia (CAS # 7664-41-7), and natural gasoline.  Anhydrous ammonia is used to control pH and supply nitrogen in the cook/fermentation process. It is stored outside in an 18,000 gallon storage tank near the center of the ethanol plant. When filled to the maximum 85% capacity, this tank can hold up to 15,300 gallons of anhydrous ammonia.  This material is a gas at ambient temperature and pressure.  It is a liquid when stored under pressure inside the tank.



Anhydrous ammonia is not a poison, but it is an inhalation / respiratory hazard. Ammonia is a toxic material but it has no cumulative effects on the human body.  However, it is acutely corrosive when it comes into contact with mucous membranes, in particular.   Anhydrous ammonia is a non-flammable gas.



Natural gasoline is used to denature the ethanol.  Natural gasoline is a flammable mixture.  There are multiple constituents of natural gasoline however, based on analysis, four of those constituents, butane, pentane, neo-pentane or 2,2-dimethylpropane, and iso-pentane or 2-methylbutane are subject to the Risk Management Plan.  Butane makes up 0.806% of the natural gasoline, pentane makes up 24.518%, neo-pentane or 2,2-dimethylpropane makes up 0.237%, and iso-pentane or 2-methylbutane makes up 22.96%.



Natural gasoline i

s stored in a 235,000 gallon steel tank in the facility's tank farm.  Secondary containment consisting of compacted clay surrounds the tank farm.



Summary of Release Scenarios



Worst Case Release



Ammonia: 

As mentioned above, the storage tank has an 18000 gallon capacity, but when filled to 85%, it can only hold 15,300 gallons or 85,527 pounds of ammonia.   All deliveries are made by truck, which holds 20 tons (40,000 pounds) of ammonia.  The worst case release scenario would occur while the delivery truck is hooked up to the storage tank during the receiving process.   A truck is only ordered when the storage tank can receive the entire truckload.  So, 85,527 pounds of storage capacity - 40,000 pounds of empty space required to be able to order and receive a truckload of ammonia + 40,000 pound of ammonia on the delivery truck = 85,527 pounds of product that is capable of being released during the worst case scenario.



A complete failure or burst of the ammonia storage tank, as represented by the worst case scenario, is highly unlikely.  The bulk storage tank was built in 2006 under strict guidelines established by the ASME pressure vessel code.  The National Board Certificate for the tank is on file.  The storage tank is protected by concrete traffic barriers.  All welding and structural work done on the tanks or appendages are performed by certified welders and stamped accordingly.



Natural Gasoline:

The worst case release scenario would be a total loss of a full tank of natural gasoline resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  The storage tank capacity is 235,000 gallons or 1.3 million pounds.  Of the 1.3 million pounds, 615,885 pounds are made up of the materials subject to the Risk Management Plan.



Alternative Release



Ammonia:

The most likely causes of ammonia emergencies are ruptured hoses and defective valves, as represented by the alternative release scenario.  The most probable time for an exposure to occur will be during a transfer from a

ine tanks or transfer pipes.  Copies of all reports are on file. The ammonia and natural gasoline systems undergoes a thorough inspection by a third party at least every five years.



See "Steps Taken to Address Hazards" for more information on prevention measures and identification.





Management System



(see "Steps Taken to Address Hazards")



Equipment maintenance



All equipment maintenance is formally documented. See the "Prevention Program" section for further explanation.



Training



All employees receive annual training on anhydrous ammonia, flammable liquids, emergency action plan, spill procedures, and hazard communication.  Documentation and attendance rosters are on file at the facility.  







Contractors



Contractors that are hired by THE ANDERSONS MARATHON HOLDINGS LLC will go through a documented Prequalification process.  Records of this evaluation are kept on file.



All contractors also receive a "contractor safety review" prior to performing work at the facility.  During this review, they are informed of any potential hazards at the facility, emergency procedures, site-specific safety rules and the ability to request a SDS for any product at any time.



Steps Taken to Address Hazards



The Andersons Ethanol LLC has many systems in place for hazard assessment and mitigation.  



The Safety Department performs annual hazard management audits at the facility.  The audits include a physical walk through of the entire facility and a review of all EPA, OSHA and DOT paperwork and training documentation.  Action items are noted and recommendations are made. The audits consist of five major topical areas:  Safety & Health, Environmental, Fire Protection & Security, Administrative and Housekeeping & Storage.  Issues are documented in a report and sent to the facility manager and upper management.  Updates on action item status must be made regularly.



A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) has been performed at this facility, as part of the Pr

delivery truck to the storage tank.  Flexible hoses must be connected properly.  Hoses are date-stamped and replaced by the transporter or The Andersons in advance of the expiration date or when defects are observed.  All transfers of ammonia are directly observed by the delivery truck driver.  Transfers of anhydrous ammonia from the storage tank to the processing building occur inside fixed steel pipes and area automated from the control room.  No hoses are utilized in the operation.



Under normal circumstances for the alternative scenario, the amount released would not be based on the total volume of both vessels.  Instead, it would be limited by the volume of the delivery truck.  The plumbing at the storage vessel receiving bulkhead has backflow preventers which would prevent the tank from emptying its contents if a transfer hose ruptured.  Therefore, the product that would be released would have to come from the delivery truck.  



Anhydrous ammonia is supplied by a tanker truck, which holds 20 tons (40,000 pounds) of product.  Product is transferred via rubber hoses to the storage tank at a rate of 1,000 pounds / minute.  The truck has an excess flow valve and the receiving system at the tank also has one.  Typically, a release would immediately trigger the excess flow valves to slam shut.  However, if the release was too slow to trigger the excess flow valve, it would continue to leak until the transfer system could be shut down.  Over the course of a ten-minute period, approximately 10,000 pounds (10 minutes x 1,000 pounds) of ammonia would be released.



Natural Gasoline:

The most likely cause of a natural gasoline emergency is a release during a delivery due to a faulty hose or valve resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  Deliveries are made by railcar and pumped into the storage tank.  Deliveries are typically 30,000 gallons or 166,000 pounds of which 78,600 pounds are RMP materials.



All unloads are made during business hours and are observed by f

acility personnel.  If a release were to occur the attendants could stop the flow within minutes.  The loadout area where deliveries occur has a catchment basin with underground piping to secondary containment.



Explanation of How Ammonia Releases are Prevented



Ammonia:

Passive mitigation refers to equipment, devices or technologies that function without human, mechanical or energy input.  The passive mitigation systems in place include:



Bulkhead breakaway units located on the connection point between the delivery truck and the storage tank plumbing.  If a truck driver were to drive off without disconnecting from the tank, the concrete structure would cause the hose to shear off from the plumbing.  At this point, active mitigation would take effect and an excess flow valve, just inside the breakaway barrier, would prevent the tank from emptying into the atmosphere.



Active mitigation refers to equipment, devices or technologies that require human, mechanical or other energy input to function.  The active mitigation systems in place include:



Excess flow valves are located on all outgoing liquid and vapor valves on both storage tanks.  They close automatically if the volume of gas or liquid flowing through the line exceeds the normal flow rate.  They won't reopen until the downstream shutoff valve is closed and the pressure equalizes on both sides of the valve seat.  Two principal causes of the excess valve closing are a ruptured hose or a broken pipe or shutoff valve downstream that is opened too quickly.



Back check valves are located on the unloading lines of delivery trucks and are designed to ensure that the flow goes in one direction only.  This prevents anhydrous ammonia from flowing back to the transport tank from the storage tank.



Pressure-relief valves are located on the top of the bulk storage tanks, fixed steel piping and on the vaporizer to relieve pressure that is too great.  This can be caused by elevated temperatures in the summer or

overfilling.  They open directly to the atmosphere at 250 psig and close when the pressure inside the tank drops below this pressure.



An emergency shutoff cord, located along the side of the anhydrous ammonia bulk storage tank activates the emergency shutoff valves ("snappy joes") on the discharge side of the ammonia pump.  This stops the flow of ammonia by remote activation of a spring loaded valve.



An ample supply of water is available near the bulk storage tank from a nearby water tank and a water hydrant to help knock down a vapor cloud.



Spill control kits are located at the facility and include sorbent material, shovels, PPE and disposal containers.



Deliver truck drivers supervise all anhydrous transfers to and from the bulk storage tank



Natural Gasoline:



Passive Mitigation

The natural gasoline storage and unloading areas are equipped with secondary containment.  Material released from unloading will stay in the concrete secondary containment pad.  Electrical equipment in the tank farm area is rated for Class 1 Division 1 to prevent any leakage from being ignited by electrical equipment. 



Active Mitigation

Hot work in the unloading area and tank farm is strictly controlled by hot work permits.  Unloading operations are attended at all times.  All of the fire hydrant(s) around the tank farm are equipped with water cannons to allow for fire suppression/control from a safe distance.  





Prevention Program



Preventive maintenance is an integral piece of this facility's hazard management program.  All hoses, tanks, valves and storage units are inspected at least monthly.  A good PM program is our strongest defense against a release of anhydrous ammonia or natural gasoline.  All hose replacements are documented.  Records of all maintenance tasks performed on the tank or appendages are also on file.



This facility uses a certified third party contractor for all welding and construction performed on the anhydrous ammonia and natural gasol

ocess Safety Management Program.  The analysis will be updated every five years, or as changes in the processes are made.  PHA's are performed using the Haz Op protocol and analyze all aspects involved in the production of ethanol.  The evaluation team includes representatives from the corporate Safety Department, facility Management and Operations employees.



Standard operating procedures have been established for all activities related to the natural gasoline storage and handling.  These procedures are reviewed annually by employees and management to ensure they are current.  The procedures are available to the employees at the facility in hard copy and in an electronic database. 



Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted prior to start-up after major shutdowns and/or changes to the process.  These reviews ensure that the process has been restored to a safe operating condition prior to beginning operations.  The reviews are documented and those forms are kept on file at the facility.



Formal investigations are performed for all environmental or safety incidents.  Documentation is kept on file at the facility and the corporate Safety Department.



A formal Management of Change (MOC) system is in place at this facility.  An electronic form is submitted whenever a change is made to any of the processes within the scope of the PSM program. This ensures that appropriate documentation such as P&IDs, operating procedures, maintenance items, etc. are reviewed and updated as needed where affected by the change.  Forms are routed from the facility operator to the Engineering and Safety Departments for review and remarks.  Where changes affect operating procedures, revisions are made and employee training is completed prior to start-up of the changed process.  A copy of the completed is form kept on file at the facility.



The facility maintains compliance with environmental permits applicable to the operations.  These permits include various requirements for weekly,

monthly, and quarterly activities to prevent leaks or uncontrolled emissions of flammable materials.





Monthly Safety Committee meetings allow employees to discuss any concerns they may have with the operation of the facility.  Issues are documented and assigned to employees for follow-up. Records of all meetings are kept at the facility.



Response Action in the Event of a Release



The site has not had a significant accident within the last five years for one or more of the regulated substances from a covered process.



In the event of a small, controlled leak or defective valve, employees are instructed to shut down the transfer process and, if possible, don the appropriate PPE, approach the shutoff valve from upwind and attempt to turn it off.  Notification of site personnel would be made as soon as possible when the leak has been detected. 



For an uncontainable release, employees will immediately call the police and fire department or other first responders, as appropriate.  All employees, customers and contractors are to be evacuated to an upwind location. Once the response team has arrived, we will work in concert with them to close the valves between the tank and the leak.  In the meantime, for an ammonia leak, a steady spray of water will deluge the ammonia gas plume and knock it to the ground, while chemically binding any free ammonia.



The employees are instructed to make emergency phone calls in this order:  911, the facility Manager, the corporate Safety Department emergency phone number, the state emergency hotline and the National Spill Response Center phone number.  All applicable contact names and numbers are found in the facility spill and emergency action plan. 



Communication procedures with responders



The local fire department is invited to tour the facility on an annual basis.  Facility management, employees and fire department personnel have jointly discussed the location of the anhydrous ammonia and response procedures on a r

egular basis.  They know the location of all emergency shutoff valves and on-site response equipment.  We believe that a strong relationship with first responders is our best defense.



The LEPC and state regulatory agencies receive a copy of our hazardous materials storage information, every February, in accordance with our community right to know obligations.  A copy of the Emergency Action Plan is on file with the LEPC and the local fire department.



Security Plans



The Department of Transportation (DOT), Research and Special Programs Administration (RSPA) 49 CFR Part 172, requires all facilities that offer or transport hazardous materials to document a security plan and perform employee awareness training.  



A security assessment plan has been created to describe all security measures at this facility, identify any vulnerable areas and then document the measures taken to address those risks.  The plan is intended to work in conjunction with the Emergency Action and Spill Prevention, Control and Countermeasures Plan to meet all required criteria.



Training is performed with all employees annually and within 90 days of employment.
